div.p: ADMIRE as NOBLE AND SERVE POLITELY.
1. The current general word for typically public respectful attitudes and actions is jìng 敬 (ant. màn 慢 "fail to show proper respect for").
2. Gōng 恭 (ant. jù 倨 "behave in an informal impolite way") refers specifically to private proper polite and respectful attitudes shown to a deserving person.

3. Zūn 尊 (ant. bǐ 鄙 "consider as not worthy of any veneration or respect") refers to psychological public or private respect for someone in a very exalted social, cultural, religious and/or political position, and the degree of public respect is much greater that that in jìng 敬 and reaches into the past to ancestors.
4. Chóng 崇 and zōng 宗 refers to distant and typically religious veneration of a spirit or person very highly regarded. SHI 靡神不宗 "there are no spirits which we have not honoured"
5. Lǐ 禮 (ant. màn 慢 "treat without proper ritual respect") refers to a proper show of public demonstrative respect for someone on the part of a host or a superior.
6. Wèi 畏 (ant. xiá 狎 "treat without the proper respect due to someone in high position, treat with improper familiarity") refers to awe-struck respect for a person in authority.
7. Lóng 隆 typically refers to due diligent respect for abstract values.
8. Qīn 欽 is an archaic courtly word referring to formal conformity with the rules of polite respect for superiors on public occasions.
9. Zhī 知 focusses on proper appreciation of a person, accompanied by recognition of that person's worth.
rough draft to BEGIN TO identify synonym group members for analysis, based on CL etc. 18.11.2003. CH ／
Jìng 敬 stresses concern for others and for business at hand, gōng 恭 stresses respectful polite behavior as such.

sense.def: humble oneself before> show reverence to 下人"(as a superior) treat others with respect" to treat with humility, treat deferentially (persons whom one is not obliged to treat that way); mix congenially with (those who are of lower status)

entry.def: Gōng 恭 (ant. jù 倨 "behave in an informal impolite way") refers specifically to private proper polite and respectful attitudes shown to a deserving person.
Gōng 恭 (ant. jù 倨 "behave in an informal impolite way") refers specifically to private proper polite and respectful attitudes shown to a deserving person.

sense.def: humble respectfulness, humility, humble politeness; polite correctness in behaviour
show one's humble respect to others as required by etiquette; be respectful and polite to others
ensure that (someone) is polite and respectful, ensure that (someone) shows humble politeness
show exceedingly polite (religious) respect for; show great respect for (SHI also: the common people??????)

entry.def: Chóng 崇 and zōng 宗 refers to distant and typically religious veneration of a spirit or person very highly regarded. SHI 靡神不宗"there are no spirits which we have not honoured"

sense.def: pay one's respects to (as in an ancestral temple)
pay one's high and religious respects to (someone) as one's ancestor or as a revered spirit
be held in the highest esteem

entry.def: Zūn 尊 (ant. bǐ 鄙 "consider as not worthy of any veneration or respect") refers to public respect for someone in a very exalted social, cultural, religious and/or political position, and the degree of public respect is much greater that that in jìng 敬 and reaches into the past to ancestors.

sense.def: show proper reverential respect for; venerate, revere, show respect for; treat with demonstrative respect
be treated with respect, enjoy respect
cause to be highly respected; elevate to a respectful position; show respect for
(regard as distinguished>) to honour as deserving public respect; ensure position of public honour and esteem;

entry.def: Chóng 崇 and zōng 宗 refers to distant and typically religious veneration of a spirit or person very highly regarded. SHI 靡神不宗"there are no spirits which we have not honoured"

sense.def: pay due respect to; to hold in very high esteem, admire
being revered: reverence shown to one
be respectful and diligent (with respect to things)
archaic/poetic, SHI, SHU: make a diligent and earnest show of respect

entry.def: The current general word for respectful attitudes and actions is jìng 敬 (ant. màn 慢 "fail to show proper respect for").

sense.def: earnest and respectful diligence; respectful devotion
show the proper and required respect for the contextually determinate object
show respect where respect is due
show proper respect for; show obedient unquestioning respect for
cause to be or become respected
feel respect for and act earnestly on the basis of this
ensure that N is diligent and respectful
feel/show more respect for; show the primary respect for; fhow and feel most respect for
show one's respect by visiting the court of
show one's respect to at court
cause N to pay respect at court

entry.def: Qīn 欽 is an archaic courtly word referring to formal conformity with the rules of polite respect for superiors on public occasions.

sense.def: hold in high esteem and respect

entry.def: Wèi 畏 (ant. xiá 狎 "treat without the proper respect due to someone in high position, treat with improper familiarity") refers to awe-struck respect for a person in authority.

sense.def: stand in awe of those in authority
be respected, be held in awe
HS, Dongfang Shuo: admire as outstanding, stand in awe of
畏天之威"fear the authority of Heaven": cognate with wēi 威 "authority"] fear and revere; stand in fearful awe of
stand in awe of a person

entry.def: Zhī 知 focusses on proper appreciation of a person, accompanied by recognition of that person's worth.

sense.def: appreciate properly, recognise (a person for his true value); repect properly for what a person is
be appreciated properly, be respected properly; be understood properly
archaic/poetic, SHI, SHU: be respectfully diligent

entry.def: Lǐ 禮 (ant. màn 慢 "treat without proper ritual respect") refers to a proper show of public demonstrative respect for someone on the part of a host or a superior.

sense.def: show proper respect to; treat with proper politeness See HOSPITALITY 甚禮之
show respect to; treat with polite consideration; pay special ritual respect to
gravely; seriously, with serious respectful diligence
lift clothes as a sign of respect
attach importance to> show respect for
regard as being of great importance and as deserving great respect (a person or a thing); treat as important
be regarded with great respect (by someone)

entry.def: Lóng 隆 typically refers to due diligent respect for abstract values.

sense.def: hold in high public esteem, show deep reverence for (as for ritual, or for a teacher)
what is highly respectable, in XUN coming close to metonymy for the ritual
proper respectful reverence and diligence in the performance of one's duties
show every kind of respectful diligence in action
show great respect to the contextually determinate N
respect; show a politely considerate attitude towards

entry.def: respectfully to do one's devoted best

sense.def: show respect for the contextually determinate N

BUDDH: ?? express one's respect and gratitude through bowing to; to ritually bow to N as expression of gratitude
show one's respect to the contextually determinate N
show one's respect to (by paying a visit)
be held in high esteem; be appreciated and respected
cause N to be held in high esteem; make N respectable
approach earnestly and with full respect
respectfully pulling up one garment in order to avoid stumbling> respectfully
(possibly = gong1yi4 恭翼) be respectful, to show respect
respect the contextually determinate N as (one does) one's elders
respect as being of superior importance
respect as being of major importance
mutual respect of the highest order
